content.body:
> <@bakkot:matrix.org> `({ __proto__: { x: 0 }, m(){ return super.x; } }).m()` returns 0

Why super is valid in that context?
content.formatted_body:
In reply to @bakkot:matrix.org
({ __proto__: { x: 0 }, m(){ return super.x; } }).m() returns 0
Why super is valid in that context?

content.body: devsnek: speaking very pedantically it's not required there; it happens that it doesn't throw, and you don't need the completion record, so it is not incorrect to just do the step and ignore the result rather than doing the step and asserting that the result is not abrupt
content.formatted_body: devsnek: speaking very pedantically it's not required there; it happens that it doesn't throw, and you don't need the completion record, so it is not incorrect to just do the step and ignore the result rather than doing the step and asserting that the result is not abrupt

content.body: would that be lawful evil or chaotic evil
Jack Works: modulo some details about HomeObject, `super.x` mostly just means "access `.x` but on the prototype"; regular objects have prototypes too, so why shouldn't it be valid?
content.formatted_body: Jack Works: modulo some details about HomeObject, super.x mostly just means "access .x but on the prototype"; regular objects have prototypes too, so why shouldn't it be valid?
